misconceptions.name: Implemented distance formula program instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points rather than reading a single numeric grade and printing the corresponding letter grade based on the specified ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to read two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and compute the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read one numeric grade between 0 and 100 from the user and use conditional statements to map that grade into a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) according to the given ranges, then print that letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of a single grade value.
Program calculates a distance using the square root of squared differences instead of checking grade ranges.
Program outputs a numeric distance with the message 'The distance of the two points is ...' instead of 'Letter grade: ...'.
No conditional logic implementing grade ranges (90-100 A, 80-89 B, etc.) is present.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misreading or misremembering the assignment, or reusing code from a different exercise (distance between two points) without adapting it to the grade calculator specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and start by planning the correct input and output: a single numeric grade in, a single letter grade out. Then design if/else-if conditions that check the numeric ranges for A, B, C, D, and F, and print the corresponding letter.
related_concepts: Program design based on a textual description
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All input prompts, variables, calculations, and output messages match a standard distance-between-points exercise and do not reference grades or letter outputs at all.

evidence.note: Code reads two coordinate pairs, computes their distance, and prints that result instead of reading a single grade and outputting a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Did not attempt the requested problem
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points (a common introductory programming problem) instead of implementing the required Grade Calculator problem based on a numeric grade input and conditional logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student submitted code for a different assignment/problem, possibly believing it was the required solution or failed to replace template code.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The requirement was to read a single numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to output a letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Code name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints'
Reads four double inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2)
Performs calculations for distance formula (square root, differences squared)
Outputs 'The distance of the two points is...'
No conditional logic (if/else if/else) present
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding or misfiling of the assignment requirement, leading to the submission of irrelevant code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt for Q3 ('Grade Calculator') and implement the necessary input prompt, conditional logic, and output required to map a numeric grade to a letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code implements a completely different, unrelated problem (distance formula) and fails every requirement of the 'Grade Calculator' task.

evidence.note: The class name suggests a completely different program than the required Grade Calculator.
The input reads four double coordinates, not a single integer grade (0-100).

evidence.snippet: double distanceBetweenPoints = Math.sqrt(xDifference * xDifference + yDifference * yDifference);
evidence.note: The core logic is calculating distance, not applying grading rules.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a completely different problem (calculating distance between two points) instead of the assigned grade calculator problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should write a program to calculate the distance between two points using the Euclidean distance formula.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires a grade calculator that reads a numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program reads x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a single numeric grade
Program calculates distance using the formula: sqrt((x2-x1)² + (y2-y1)²)
Program outputs a distance value instead of a letter grade
No conditional logic for grade ranges (A, B, C, D, F)
No letter grade output whatsoever
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either misread the assignment, copied code from a different problem, or confused this question with another assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The program should: 1) Read ONE numeric grade value (0-100), 2) Use if-else statements to check which range the grade falls into, 3) Output the corresponding letter grade. Start fresh with the correct problem in mind.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence - the submitted code solves an entirely different problem. There is no ambiguity: the code calculates Euclidean distance between points, not letter grades. This is not a minor logic error but a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment itself.

evidence.note: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a single numeric grade (0-100)

evidence.snippet:
double distanceBetweenPoints = Math.sqrt(xDifference * xDifference + yDifference * yDifference);

System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distanceBetweenPoints);
evidence.note: Calculates and outputs Euclidean distance instead of determining and outputting a letter grade
Class name 'DistanceBetweenPoints' reflects the wrong problem entirely; should relate to grade calculation

misconceptions.name: Implemented distance formula instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points rather than reading a numeric grade and outputting the corresponding letter grade according to the specified ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to read two coordinate points (x1, y1, x2, y2) and compute the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100, then use conditional statements to determine and print the correct letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the given ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1 and y1, and x2 and y2 instead of a single numeric grade.
The code performs geometric distance calculations using the square root of squared differences.
There are no conditionals to map numeric grade ranges to letter grades.
Output message describes the distance of two points rather than a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation or confusion about the problem requirements, possibly mixing up this question with a different assignment about distance between points.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and redesign the program to: (1) read one numeric grade value from input, and (2) use an if-else chain (or equivalent) to map the grade to the correct letter grade, then print it.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the code (input prompts, variables, calculations, and output) corresponds to a distance-between-points problem and none of it addresses reading a grade or mapping ranges to letter grades.

evidence.note: All inputs and computations relate to coordinates and distance, not to reading a single grade and computing a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misinterpretation of Assignment Goal
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a different problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the required Grade Calculator problem. This indicates a failure to understand or follow the core requirements of Q3.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were asked to write a program that calculates the distance between two points, or they unintentionally submitted code for a different question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting a letter grade (A, B, C, D, F) based on conditional logic (if/else if/else).
symptoms: Code implements standard distance formula (Math.sqrt((x2-x1)^2 + (y2-y1)^2))
Code prompts for four coordinate inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2)
Code contains no conditional logic (if/else) related to grading.
The class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the assignment prompt, submitting the wrong file, or confusing Q3 requirements with another problem, leading to a complete logical deviation from the task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully reread the requirement for Q3: Grade Calculator. Delete the distance calculation logic and replace it with code that reads a single grade and maps it to a letter using if/else if/else structures.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code calculates Euclidean distance, which is entirely unrelated to the Grade Calculator problem described in the instructions and rubric. This is a complete failure to address the stated requirement.

evidence.note: The entire program implements the distance formula, not the grade calculation.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student misunderstood the assignment and wrote a program to calculate the distance between two points instead of creating a grade calculator that evaluates numeric grades and outputs letter grades.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment was asking for a program that calculates Euclidean distance between two coordinate points.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires a program that reads a single numeric grade (0-100), checks it against specified ranges (A: 90-100, B: 80-89, C: 70-79, D: 60-69, F: <60), and outputs the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a grade
Program applies distance formula instead of grade range logic
Output shows distance calculation instead of letter grade
No conditional statements to check grade ranges
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misread or confused the assignment description; possibly worked on the wrong problem or mixed up instructions from a different assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the assignment. The program should: (1) read ONE numeric value (the grade), (2) use if-else conditionals to check which range it falls into, (3) output the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is entirely unrelated to the grade calculator problem. There is no ambiguity here—the code solves a different problem entirely.

evidence.snippet:

System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distanceBetweenPoints);
